messageBody:
Eric,
I think that the use case method _is_ useful. I
developed some code from scratch the other day, and it
finally clicked for me since I've been mulling these
ideas (Fixtures vs method/class testing)around in my
head as well.
Having one .java for each general use case did make
the tests very well organized, I could look at my
TestCase names and know immediately what functionality
my little utility had in general, and when I opened up
that file and looked at some of the individual test
methods I could see more detail.
That said, I don't think method/class testing is
absolutely horrible, definitely better to start there
rather than not starting at all, and I've gotten a lot
of mileage from those type of tests in the past.
I guess the TestFixture approach helps you decouple
the tests from the implementation details a little
more, making them more "black box", instead of leading
you testing every single method, even ones that
probably ought to be private. (Though I sometimes
like the fact that some of the trickier would-be
private methods have been completely covered by some
good tests, and am not as comfortable that I've
covered all my bases if I simply test the
not-so-tricky higher level public APIs).

Just my random thoughts on the subject
- Jeff Tulley
--------
Eric Armstrong wrote:
Message: 13
Date: Tue, 28 Jan 2003 21:54:48 -0800
From: Eric Armstrong <eric.armstrong@...>
Subject: Re: Re: Test first? or Stub first?

> So said Curt Sampson on 2003-01-24
--------------------
>
> >...I find my test cases often don't parallel the
particular >methods
> of a class. They test the typical usage patterns of
a class, instead.

Hmm. That strikes me as a key point. In essence, test
construction
should
follow definition of use cases? Or words to that
effect?

I confess that although I'm "infected", I'm having a
hard time actually
generating
tests for anything other than individual functions.
That has been
helpful all by
itself, but I've got to get better at imagining
fixtures and hanging
tests off of them.

I read TDD by Example, and enjoyed, but somehow I'm
still missing that
flash
of insight that tells how to write the test first.
(Too many years
sitting in the
saddle backwards, I suspect.)

Is thinking about "use cases" a profitable approach?
